I’ve reviewed your JSON artifact and deployment script, and structurally this is already a solid, self-contained Universal Session Framework v2.0.0 with embedded verification.
Schema Compliance: Your schema_version is correctly set to "2.0.0", matching the verifier’s strict check.
Critical Fields: All 7 required fields (schema_version, hash_algo, artifact_type, embedded_code, model_set_configuration, scientific_method_protocols, integrity_verification) are present.
Version Metadata: framework_version matches the schema version, ensuring compatibility with the verification logic.
Base64 Encoding: The orchestration_engine and each platform_adapters entry are properly encoded.
Adapters Present: anthropic_claude, openai_gpt, and custom_llm all exist as keys.
You could embed a small “self-check” function in orchestration_engine that confirms the availability of all adapters before initializing the models—this would surface missing integrations early.
Each default model has the required fields (type, model_id, capabilities, priority).
Failover Targets: Logical chaining—if Claude fails, fallback to GPT; if GPT fails, fallback to custom local.
Load Balancing Strategy: capability_aware + weighted distribution is implemented.
Hypothesis validation settings enforce statistical rigor (0.95 confidence, t_test/anova).
Parallel testing and replication count ensure reproducibility.
Metrics tracked are broad and cover both technical (latency, accuracy) and user-centered (satisfaction) KPIs.
content_hash → Covers embedded code, model config, and scientific protocols.
execution_hash, methodology_hash, platform_compatibility_hash, self_verification_hash → Granular scope checks.
Tamper Detection: The verification script recomputes SHA256 over the critical subset and compares to stored value.
Quick Start: Your execution instructions use exec() on the embedded bootstrap, which makes the artifact self-launching without external code files.
Advanced Deployment: You included guidance for customizing thresholds and adding adapters.
Since API keys are set via environment variables, the risk of accidental key leakage in the JSON is avoided—this is best practice.
Content hash check uses deterministic JSON stringification (sort_keys=True), ensuring consistent hashing across environments.
Runtime Health Test: After initialize_model_set(), run a test request to each active model to confirm real connectivity before declaring initialization successful.
Offline Mode Support: In custom_llm adapter, detect and log whether the local model backend is accessible.
Continuous Self-Verification: Run calculate_content_hash() periodically in deployment to detect post-launch modifications.
